cyclone.name: NATE
cyclone.current_location: about 25 miles SSW of San Andres Island
cyclone.trajectory: System is forecast to move northwest across Nicaragua/Honduras, re-emerge into the north-western Caribbean, cross the Yucatan Channel, then accelerate north-north-eastward across the central Gulf of Mexico toward the U.S. Gulf Coast.
cyclone.expected_landfall_location: central Gulf Coast (near the MS/AL border – east of New Orleans, LA)

weather_observation.watch_coast: None at this time – U.S. Gulf Coast watches not yet issued in Advisory #1
weather_observation.warning_coast: None along U.S. Gulf Coast – current warnings confined to Nicaragua and Honduras
weather_observation.impacted_coast: Potential impact zone from southeast Louisiana eastward across Mississippi, Alabama, and the western Florida Panhandle
weather_observation.wind: Low (14%) chance of sustained tropical-storm-force winds (≥34 kt) reaching the port late Saturday night into Sunday; 50-kt wind probability only 3%.
weather_observation.storm_surge: Early guidance suggests the potential for 3 ft or greater surge on east-facing shores of southeast Louisiana if the center tracks just east of the Mississippi Delta.
weather_observation.rainfall: Bands associated with NATE could deliver 3–6 inches with isolated higher totals to southeast Louisiana Sunday, producing localized flooding.
weather_observation.other_hazards: Brief tornadoes in outer rainbands and port access restrictions due to elevated seas in approaches to the Mississippi River.
